item.title: Migrating sub-select MySQL query to Presto
item.description: When you have working SQL query there might not be so simple and straightforward it’s migration to Presto SQL. Recently I had a job to extract data from one table but with multiple added columns which requires sub-select. To demonstrate the problem and solution I have prepared simple user and location table where location entry represents where and where have users moved. User +----+-------+ | id | name | +----+-------+ | 1 | Tom | | 2 | Sally | | 3 | Ben | +----+-------+ Location +----+---------+-------------+----------------------+ | id | user_id | name | moved_on | +----+---------+-------------+----------------------+ | 1 | 1 | 'New York' | '2010-1-1 00:00:00' | | 2 | 1 | 'Columbus' | '2011-1-1 00:00:00' | | 3 | 1 | 'Miami' | '2012-1-1 00:00:00' | | 4 | 2 | 'Miami' | '2010-1-1 00:00:00' | | 5 | 2 | 'Columbus' | '2011-1-1 00:00:00' | | 6 | 3 | 'Miami' | '2010-1-1 00:00:00' | | 7 | 3 | 'New York' | '2011-1-1 00:00:00' | +----+---------+-------------+----------------------+ Solution is using Presto’s window function

item.title: How to become a blockchain developer — the first thing
item.description: tl;dr Blockchain A-Z™: Learn How To Build Your First Blockchain I passed some online courses and read a lot of resources to become blockchain developer, even 100x more expensive ones. The first thing you need is to get basic idea how blockchain works, what are its use cases and what are its limitations in order to understand documentation of blockchain you are interested in. Only after that you can develop smart contracts you need and Blockchain A-Z course will give you all of that: basic background and some idea about smart contracts on Etherium blockchain.

item.title: Calculating Huge Number Modulo
item.description: I have stumbled upon a task to calculate modulo of 5 * (2¹⁰)¹⁸ where mod = 10⁹+7 Using multiplication formula x * y % mod = ((x % mod) * (y % mod)) % mod we can first split our problem to (n % mod) * ((2 ¹⁰)¹⁸ % mod) % mod = X and then to (n % mod) * ((2 ¹⁰*¹⁸ % mod) % mod = X Modern programing languages like python can do this already in pow (exponent) function has third parameter for mod.

item.title: Debugging C/C++ code in Visual Studio Code (VSC)
item.description: I’ve been occupied with competitive programing a lot lately. For writing code I use Visual Studio Code because I am used to it from javascript and python world. To test code I write given input from competition task to in.txt file and then run custom task build. Steps needed for running/debugging: 1. install C/C++ extension. https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/languages/cpp 2. Define task to build code. Go to Tasks > Configure tasks and choose your task to edit or create new one.
